data.title: good eats
data.text: Two of us dined there last night (6/23/16). You know the place is good when the locas go there to eat.  We had Lomo Saltado and Chicken Chaufa with a house salad. There were two waiters taking orders and about three bring the food. The guy taking our order couldn’t understand anything that was requested.  He neither understood Spanish nor English. Perhaps he was just new to the job and nervous.  Otherwise we enjoyed our meal.

data.title: Good food and you can't beat the price!!
data.text: Where else can you get a half of a large chicken, rice and beans or salad for $8 dollars...enough for 2 meals.  Nice people, popular restaurant judging from the crowds

data.title: Love the Lomo Saltado
data.text: I've dinned here several times over the past couple years. Their service is so-so, but the food is tasty and they have good portion sizes. I enjoy the lomo salted, which is a variation of a beef stir-fry, but served over french fries with a side of white rice. I also enjoy this green sauce in which you dip your bread. No idea what it's called, but it is tasty! I noticed that there's a Groupon offer available now as well  - even better.

data.title: fiesta atlantic delivery
data.text: Never been to Fiesta in Atlantic street ever in my life because I live on Shippan ave and there use to be one right next to me, which I love their Choros a la Chalacas. I found them amazing. Now the old fiesta is called Viva. I don't know why, but hey am not a cop or a lawyer to be in fiesta company affairs. I do know that I love Choros a la Chalaca :-) To the point... I order more than one order at a time from Atlantic street just so they can delivery it to me, and not go out of there way just for one order and I don't have to pick it up at Viva;-). Call me lazy or maybe is just the cold winter days, but I am a very unhappy camper to the night of February 14(7:15pm ) I must say that the delivery service of Fiesta from Atlantic street is just not up to par. They don't understand estimate on delivery time. If they tell you is going to be 2 hours, IT IS going to be 2 hours. You could be located right next to them and it will still be 2 hours. So, don't take them lightly when they tell you what time you going to be eating. In addition, the delivery personnel feels like they doing you a favor on bring you the food 2 hours later, so please don't forget to tip them 20% for this fact. My main point to Fiesta is your food is great, you have a good thing going for you... Don't mess it up if you don't have the proper staff to deliver. Just as an F.Y.I Chanel Rodas (OWNER)... The old Fiesta right next to me didn't delivery and I didn't mind picking it up because Fiesta's food was that good. I just don't like you to sell me a service and think you guys are doing me a favor because you are delivering oppose to me picking up my food.

data.title: coming back
data.text: i have passed by this place many times and it is always crowded so my assumption was it had to be good. finally walked in to try the place and ordered the lomo soltado. i have to say it was pretty good and was exactly what i expected. service was very fast and the waitresses were very friendly and accommodating. would i come back again?  definitely! i have to try their other dishes like the a la pobre so i can compare.

data.title: Great Food, Terrible Service
data.text: A bunch of us went for dinner.  The food was great but the service was the worst service I have ever had.  The restuarant was not even crowded.  Unfortunate.  Loved the meat and the shrimp dishes.  Not sure if I would go back.

data.title: good lunch, good value, made  to order
data.text: Had lunch at Fiesta Atlantic yesterday and it was very good.  We had the Lomo Saltado.  Excellent value for the price.  Good quantity, tasty, attentive service.  A little heavy on the starch - fries and rice - but that may be the Peruvian way.  It does not seem to be the place to go if you're in a hurry since they appear to make everything to order but it was well worth the wait.  Will definitely return.

data.title: Ihope get better
data.text: Today 11/21/2015 I just came back from the restaurant, I was with my family :Wife and Son we were seated right away but we waited  about 5+ minutes for the waitress MARLY to take our order because she was eating in the counter with another waitress in front of everybody, the service was so poor the food did not taste at all as  peruvian food. the Pollo a la brasa tasted as boiled no broiled too dry, tallarines verdes and a simple fried fish tasted more like Colombian food than Peruvian which is fine if the restaurant is going to be Colombian cause the food taste sooooo simple the refreshment Chicha Morada too sweet and I am not planing to comeback....I always think if you don't want to work  don't go to work you need to change your servers and of course try to hire a peruvian chef from the coast of Peru maybe he is going to be able to  help you

data.title: Really good Sangria and very tasty food!!!
data.text:
I go every week to Fiesta for lunch. I think it has a delicious food and it taste like home. The place is very cozy and the waitress are always friendly.
My favorite is the entree, which is a few pieces of bread and their special avocado sauce. I always ask for more!!!
Another favorite is the bistec a la pobre, which is a huge steak with rice, fried egg and french fries. I like to order a side of beans too. This dish servers 2 people easily. 
If you are in the mood for some alcohol, you should definitely try their Sangria.

data.title: We'll Be Back
data.text: It was difficult for the two of us to decide what to order among the unique Peruvian specialties on the menu.  Although the special lunch menu was enticing, we ordered from the regular menu for our first visit here.  We chose the Parichuela (fish soup) and the medium size order of Ceviches from the regular menu.  Both were outstanding and plentiful; we each took some home for the next day's lunch.   Next time we'll order from the special daily lunch menu: I have my eye on the 1/2 rotisserie chicken with Peruvian spices, or should it be the Chaufas (specially seasoned fried rice)?

data.title: Big on flavor and big on portions
data.text:
This place serves up large portions and amazing Peruvian cuisine.

One visit and you'll likely be back for more.

If you want to enjoy your meal in one sitting, be careful not to eat too much of the complementary and delicious Aji sauce that is served with warm bread while you wait for your entree; that can easily fill you up. Though, no hang ups about asking for a doggy bag in this intimate, family-style restaurant.

data.title: Delicious
data.text: We love fiesta lumeña in normal so thought we would try Stamford. Food was great and portions big. Prices are reasonable. Simply a good meal.

data.title: Delicious and different
data.text: First of all, you need to know that portions are HUGE! I was so indecisive about the entrees that I went with the unusual potato salad (beautifully cooked cold boiled potatoes smothered in a cheesy dressing-sauce) and a fish soup. As others have mentioned, the bread and sauce was very tasty indeed. The $7 soup was big enough for a main dish, lovely and fresh-tasting with not little pieces of fish but an entree-sized portion. I had also ordered a side of fried yucca just to try it, but it was also very big and very starchy--now I know! It would be really good with a salad or something, especially at just $3. I made room for very nice tres leches cake. This is the first time I've had Peruvian food and I'm smitten! The place was bustling with all ages--couples, families, seniors, and all ethnicities. I will definitely be back when I'm in Stamford again!

data.title: Outstanding food
data.text:
The place is soo delicious, we showed this place to all our friends who visited Stamford or who've just moved there. Lomo soltado is our favorite.
Of course there is a question what kind of meat they serve for that little price, but the taste of the meat is very good. This place could be my favorite if only they sold organic.

data.title: Great Peruvian food for a reasonable price
data.text: Whenever we want Peruvian food, we go to Fiesta Atlantic and are always pleasantly surprised.  The food is tasty and the portions huge (I almost always get two meals per entree).  We only eat veggie and chicken, so we stick to the standards like saltado,  the lo mein or the pesto noodles; and wash it down with a Diet Inca Cola.

data.title: Lima in CT
data.text:
Our group of three couples were interested in trying a new Latin American cuisine, and we were delighted to try Fiesta Atlantic, conveniently located in downtown Stamford. The restaurant's ambience is simple but clean; service was very attentive; and there was a constant flow of enthusiastic patrons. There are both booths and open tables for seating.  Unfortunately FA is only licensed to serve wine and beer, so alas, no Pisco Sours! But that was our only disappointment of the evening, as there was an ample supply  of cold Peruvian beer and a drinkable jug Chardonnay.

The portions are more than abundant.  For starters we tried the ceviches (based on fish, mixed seafood, or shrimp), and all three preparations were presented on a large plate accompanied by yucca, camote, separated choclo kernels and corn nuts and were perfectly marinated; the aji en gallina served over a large boiled potato, was both rich and tasty; and the choclo and white cheese appetizer featured a large corn cob with the huge, separated kernels.  All left us feeling we had almost had enough for a full meal. Hot, fresh bread was served with a tasty, zesty in-house aji sauce. 

For the main course, their speciality and "most ordered" plates are the different saltados, chicken, seafood, and, of course, lomo, accompanied by french fries and mountains of rice. No question these dishes were prepared home-style. The other main dish ordered was the milanesa de carne, which was a bit over-breaded, and one savvy diner ordered an appetizer portion of aji en gallina for a tasty, and more than sufficient, main dish.  

By the time we got to dessert, there was little room, but we shared two orders of a home made tres leches and it was the perfect end to a very enjoyable evening.  Although this restaurant is one of three Peruvian restaurants under the same owner, one does not get any impression that this is a "chain" operation.  Service was attentive and personable.  The one observation I would make to potential customers is that many plates may be shared and you will still come away filled to the brim.  At the end of the evening, each of the three couples said they would definitely return, as will I, having just finished a lunch comprised of the leftovers....sabroso!

data.title: Might be the best value in Stamford
data.text: Recently joined friends for a "groupon" meal at Fiesta Atlantic. Its located in the heart of Downtown Stamford a couple of doors down from the Palace Theatre.  It might be one of the best kept secrets (if it is a secret) in Stamford.  The food was very reasonably priced (even without the coupon) and abundant.  The meal begins with bread and "yellow" sauce.The sauce is incredible. We ordered appetizers including Calamari (delicious) and a dish called Aji de Gallina, which is shredded chicken mixed with a mildly spicy cream sauce served over potatoes. Outstanding. (could have been a meal itself). For the main course, I ordered the Lomo Saltado which they claim is the most requested dish.  It is a big plate of pepper steak strips sauteed with onions, tomatoes, and Peruvian seasonings, served over fries, with white rice on the side.  Fries and rice you ask?  Oh yes!  Fries and Rice.  $12.  Delicious!  There is also a chicken or shrimp version.  Oh, and did I mention the Sangria?  Best I have ever tasted.  Service was also great.  If you are looking for something a little bit different, with great food and great service, give it a try.  Oh, and take some friends.  They will be impressed that you know about this hidden gem.

data.title: Mediocre Peruvian
data.text:
Went there for dinner last night excited to get some Peruvian chicken with aji sauce. They ran out of chicken! How does a Peruvian restaurant run out of chicken? Chicken is what they do! 

I was forced to get the Lomo Saltado and even though it was good, I was disappointed about the chicken. 

We ordered two orders of the Peruvian corn choclo con queso and it was disgusting. I didn't know what it was before hand so I guess it's my fault but just a warning to someone who has never had it, this is my like regular corn. The corn is huge and tastes and feels like rubber. 

The ceviche especial was delicious according to my brother. 

Service was terrible and our waitress did not speak English. 

They had Christmas decorations still up in April. 

I will not be returning. I'll just have to make the trip to Pio Pio in the Bronx or the city.

data.title: I come for the Aji souce and Lomo Saltado
data.text:
They keep it a secret, however there is something addictive in this green stuff that makes you come back to Stamford only to visit Fiesta.
The dishes are fairly priced and the variety is adequate, so everyone can find something they like.

data.title: Good Peruvian food in Stamford
data.text: Good food at reasonable price. My mother who never had Peruvian really enjoyed it!   The chicha morada was fresh and delicious, the jalea contained delicious fresh fish, and the ceviche was very good. Pretty good service, clean restaurant.
